subject: US MARKET WRAP 1 March 2019: Stocks shrug of slate of weak US data
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar up, Treasuries down, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: US data weak, Canadian GDP miss, Kudlow and Ross positive on tariffs; Barnier ready to give UK guarantees.

* NEXT WEEK: ECB, RBA, BOC Rate Decisions, Australian Building Approvals, Business Inventories & Company Profits, UK Construction PMI, EZ Sentix Index, US Construction Spending, Earnings from Salesforce

* US ISM MANUFACTURING (FEB): It was a disappointing report, with all of the major components falling and/or missing expectations, with little silver lining to take away. "The softness of the report is disappointing after the hefty rebounds in the Chicago PMI and Richmond Fed surveys, but none of the regional reports are consistently reliable guides to the national picture," Pantheon Macroeconomics said. "The bigger story here is that US manufacturing is being pulled into the mire by the rollover in Chinese manufacturing, which is not over yet." Pantheon sees further downside for he ISM over the next few months. "In the meantime, the message is that we have to expect falling manufacturing output and declining durable goods orders, which will be a drag on GDP growth via weaker business capex. The strength in business investment in the Q4 GDP numbers won’t be sustained. Payroll growth likely will slow a bit too, though manufacturing accounts for only 9% of payrolls. Sill, for the next few months the manufacturing data will make it look as though the Fed’s dovish lurch was the right move, though we maintain that a rethink will come in the middle of the year when the headwinds - trade, Brexit, China’s cycle, and the fading of domestic stimulus - have diminished and the tightening labour market rises up the list of policymakers’ concerns."

* US PERSONAL INCOME AND SPENDING: The data for December showed consumer spending ending the year on a soft note, with consumption falling 0.6% in the month (cons +0.3%), and personal income falling by 0.1% (cons +0.3%). "Consumer spending momentum entering Q1 looks very sluggish," Oxford Economics says, "The 0.1% decline in income growth in January is not overly worrisome, however, since it follows a strong 1% gain in December. Looking at the broader trend, both income and spending retain solid momentum with their latest annual pace at 4.3% y/y and 2.2% respectively." The consultancy also says that while today's data confirms that the economy entered 2019 with less momentum than anticipated, the reported collapse in spending is hard to square with the underlying fundamental health of the consumer sector," and looking ahead, it continues to expect slower economic activity, but cautions against a recession bias. Meanwhile, the consultancy notes that PCE inflation continues to hover around the Fed's 2% target with core inflation up 0.2%, keeping the annual pace unchanged at 1.9% y/y. "The headline PCE deflator continued to drift lower in December, up just 0.1% on the month while the annual pace slipped to a 14-month of 1.7% y/y," and "given contained inflationary pressures, the Fed's bar for implementing another rate hike this year remains relatively high."

* CANADA GDP: Canadian GDP printed 0.4% annualised in Q4 2018, missing expectations of 1.2% (and the BOC's forecast of 1.3%); the monthly December figure was down 0.1% for the second straight months. The data was a disappointment, and will only reinforce the flat pricing of the BOC rate hike trajectory in 2019. "Much of  the  softening can  be  traced back  to what we  expect will  ultimately  be  transitory weakness  in  the oil & gas sector, although household spending growth also continued to slow," RBC said.

* TRADE: Friday showed little substantial updates on the China/US trade front. NEC Director Kudlow said tremendous progress has been made in talks and that the tariff strategy has helped in them. US Commerce Secretary Ross echoed this viewpoint later on saying that the US could use tariffs and quotas to enforce a deal.

* BREXIT: UK PM May told European Council President Tusk that Brexit may have to be delayed even if MP's support her deal, as more time will be required to implement the necessary legislation. There is growing rumours that PM May’s meaningful vote for her Brexit deal might be delayed too, where Downing Street insiders said they do not think the vote will be held next week. In late trade, EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier said EU is ready to give UK further guarantees that the Irish backstop is temporary; one possibility, Barnier said, was a commitment to limit the backstop through an agreement on future relationship.

* WTI (J9) FUTURES SETTLED USD 1.42 LOWER AT USD 55.80/BBL; BRENT (J9) FUTURES SETTLED USD 1.24 LOWER AT USD 65.07/BBL. Crude prices ended the week in the red after a slew of disappointing economic data in a market that has been reluctant to rally. The week began by giving up YTD highs on the back of US President Trump tweeting his dissatisfaction for rising oil prices, before paring back losses throughout the week, supported by bullish US inventory data, but as of Friday, prices reversed and tested the weekly lows seen on Monday. “Some of the blame could be shared with weakness in February manufacturing PMI data across the globe, with China, Japan, and the Euro Zone all below 50 this month and the US weaker than in January”, analysts at Citi commented in regard to Friday’s sell-off. The supply side of the equation has been remarkably bullish this week, growing signs of commitment to the OPEC+ deal, the ongoing force majeure at Libya’s El Sharara oil field, a Nigeria cutting output in the back drop of its oilfields under looming threat from the Niger Delta Avengers, and a remarkably bullish inventory release from the DOE, reporting a draw of over 8mln bbls in a time of year that usually experiences rising stockpiles; despite all these factors, the market failed to breach above the pre-Trump tweet highs. In news flow today: Russian oil production in February was 97k BPD lower than the October reference level of 11.415mln; Libya's NOC state that El Sharara is still unsafe, but is technically ready to lift the force majeure; Russia’s Lukoil have agreed at a meeting to reach the OPEC+ cuts targets in April. Baker Hughes showed oil rigs down by 10 at 843, gas rigs up by 1 at 195, leaving total rigs down by 9 at 1038.

* SPX +0.7% at 2804, NDX +0.8% at 7151, DJI +0.4% at 26029. SECTORS: Energy +1.5%, Materials 0.0%, Industrials +0.2%, Cons Discretionary +0.9%, Cons Staples -0.2%, Healthcare +1.4%, Financials +0.5%, Tech +0.7%, Telecoms +0.7%, Utilities +0.3%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Gap (GPS) made double digit gains on Friday on its earnings report where it announced the plans to split the company into two publicly traded stocks, alongside other cost cutting measures. Tesla (TSLA) opened lower after CEO Musk announced the co. would unlikely be profitable in Q1 and lowering its price on its pinnacle Model 3 vehicle. Foot Locker (FL) surged on the open by beating top and bottom line estimates and reporting 9.7% comparable sales; supplier Nike (NKE) also followed suit. Marriott International (MAR) opened lower following a disappointing revenue figure and lowering its guidance. eBay (EBAY) made gains after initiating strategic measures in tandem with activist investors Elliot and Starboard. Caesars (CZR) was an outperformer on the announcement of three new board members supported by investor Carl Icahn. Amazon (AMZN) announced plans to launch a new low cost grocery chain, supermarket stocks (WMT, KR, TGT,COST) dipped on the news.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H9) SETTLED 10 TICKS LOWER AT 121-14. T-Note were sold, and benchmark 10-year Treasury yields rose around 5bps on the day, taking it to the key 2.75%. Much of the afternoon was categorised by rangebound price action, but in later trade the complex caught another wave of selling; many would have expected the T-Note to be bought after a bout of weak data out of the US, however, there may be a few factors explaining both the USD’s upside as well as the T-Note’s downside: firstly, the Fed is going no where anytime soon, with policy data-dependent and the central bank in wait and see mode, rates or the buck are not likely to garner much influence from monpol in absence of a new directional cue; second, as we have pointed out previously, a low FX vol environment (combined with rising stocks) can be a good backdrop for carry strategies (favouring the USD); and third, traders note that next week’s macro docket may see dovish updates from the ECB, possibly RBA and possibly even the BOC, which may end up favouring USD.

* DXY: The index looks set to end another roller-coaster week on an even keel following a firm end to February and solid 1st session of the new trading month. Upbeat or above forecast Q4 GDP helped the Greenback regain 96.000+ status from a 95.817 low, and then a stellar Chicago PMI prompted accelerated recovery gains to almost 96.400 before several G10 counterparts managed to turn the tide again. Note also, Fib resistance at 96.441 may have prevented the DXY from pushing on further and retesting highs of the week at 96.604, also posted on Monday. Back to fundamentals, Fed chair Powell’s 2 part testimony and Q&As hardly impacted the Usd as he merely reinforced policy patience due to crosswinds and conflicting impulses, but did prompt relatively pronounced bear-steepening along the Treasury curve that in turn underpinned the Buck, and particularly vs the Jpy plus other safe-haven or carry currencies.

* JPY: As noted above, the Yen has been a major loser vs the Usd and more broadly, with the headline pair back in lock-step with diverging JGB/UST spreads amidst some weak Japanese data and mainly dovish BoJ commentary as Governor Kuroda conceded no or little chance of hitting the 2% inflation target in FY 2020. Indeed, Usd/Jpy rose from a base of 110.34 to just a few pips shy of 112.00 after clearing a multiple top and purported heavy export offers at 111.00 in the process, on top of the 200 DMA. Meanwhile, the Eur/Jpy cross also jumped on Friday after news that MUFJ is planning to buy the aviation unit of Germany’s DZ Bank for Eur5.6 bn, and breached an upside chart level on the way towards 127.50.

* CAD: Another net G10 laggard, but more volatile and actually outperforming its US peer for parts of the week as oil prices rebounded. However, the Loonie suffered a sharp decline on Friday ahead of Canadian GDP data (which was released early on some vendors for the record), and more so after. For the record, q/q annualised growth came in at 0.4% vs 1.2% expected and the BoC’s 1.3% forecast, while for the month of December alone the economy contracted 0.1% and prices slumped 0.8% to virtually extinguish already faint rate hike expectations for next week. Usd/Cad is just off a new 1.3252 peak for the week vs 1.3110 at one stage.

* EUR/GBP: The single currency and Sterling have bucked the broader trend and remain on course to register strong gains vs the Dollar and other rivals, although in cross terms the Pound is winning out on latest Brexit developments from a UK standpoint. Eur/Usd has survived several set-backs/wobbles to revisit 1.1400 amidst some better than of late Eurozone surveys/data and less dovish sounding ECB rhetoric vs so called ‘source’ reports ahead of next Thursday’s policy meet. Meanwhile, Cable has soared from 1.3039 at worst to circa 1.3350 at best after a significant volte-face from UK PM May on the contentious issues of a no deal withdrawal from the EU and the March 29th Article 50 deadline that will now be put before Parliament if her current deal is rejected again. On that note, the next meaningful vote was delayed yet again from this Thursday to March 12, or perhaps some time before (Wednesday March 6th has been touted) with the no deal and extension votes to follow on consecutive days thereafter.

* AUD/NZD: The Antipodean Dollars have suffered due to multiple negative/bearish factors, including local data, dovish RBA and RBNZ vibes/guidance and external headwinds, like ongoing weakness in China’s manufacturing PMIs (official and Caixin both still sub-50, albeit the latter rebounding to just below the growth-contraction threshold). Aud/Usd is now around 0.7100 within 0.7198-0.7082 trading parameters and Nzd/Usd is hovering just above 0.6800 from 0.6901 and 0.6794 at the extremes.

* SEK/NOK: Contrasting fortunes for the Scandi Crowns, as the Sek emerges from a volatile 5 days with decent gains vs the Eur and outperforming its Nok neighbour. The catalysts/rationale, significantly stronger than expected Swedish Q4 GDP and relatively hawkish/upbeat Riksbank minutes that maintain guidance for a repo hike in H2 this year. Eur/Sek off lows and back above 10.5000, but still well down from near 10.6000 highs vs Eur/Nok at 9.7500 against a 9.7900-7000 approximate band.

* COMING-UP: Monday: US Construction Spending (Dec) Tuesday: RBA Rate Decision, Spanish Parliament dissolves, Eurozone Markit Composite & Services PMI (Final), Eurozone Retail Sales, US ISM non-Mfg, PMIs, US New Home Sales (Dec) Wednesday: BoC Rate Decision, Fed's Beige Book, Australian GDP, US & Canada Trade Balance (Dec), US Factory Orders, US New Home Sales (Jan) Thursday: ECB Rate Decision, Australian Retail Sales & Trade Balance, US & Canada Trade Balance (Jan) Friday: US & Canadian Labour Market Report. Click here for full briefing.

  • Foot Locker (FL) Q4 EPS USD 1.56 vs. exp. USD 1.40, revenue USD 2.72bln vs. exp. USD 2.19bln; SSS +9.7%. (Newswires)
  • Gap (GPS) Q4 EPS USD 0.72 vs. exp. USD 0.69, revenue USD 4.62bln vs. exp. USD 4.7bln; guides FY19 adj. EPS lower. The co. announced plans to break up into two separate publicly traded companies, as well as closing 230 stores. (Newswires)
  • Marriott (MAR) Q4 adj. EPS USD 1.44 vs. exp. USD 1.39, revenue USD 5.29bln vs. exp. USD 5.48bln. Sees FY19 & Q1 EPS below expectations. (Newswires)
  • Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) Q4 EPS USD -0.57 vs. exp. USD -0.54, revenue USD 39.8mln vs. exp. USD 45.92mln. (Newswires)
  • Nordstrom (JWN) Q4 EPS USD 1.48 vs. exp. USD 1.42, revenue USD 4.48bln vs. exp. USD 4.61bln; SSS +0.1%. Sees FY19 EPS USD 3.65-3.90 vs. exp. USD 3.67. (Newswires)
  • VMware (VMW) Q4 EPS USD 1.98 vs. exp. USD 1.88, revenue USD 2.59bln vs. exp. USD 2.5bln. Sees FY20 EPS USD 6.49 vs. exp. USD 6.65; sees FY20 revenue USD 10.3bln vs. exp. USD 9.9bln. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AbbVie (ABBV) – The pharma co. has received a positive opinion from European regulators for its psoriasis treatment, SKYRIZI. (Newswires)
  • Allergan (AGN) – Activist investor David Tepper’s Appaloosa Management said investor John Chevedden is supporting it in the push for the pharma co. to split the roles of chairman and CEO. (Newswires)
  • AT&T (T) – The HBO CEO Richard Plepler has resigned after being in the position since 2013, this comes after concerns of the unit’s autonomy following AT&T’s acquisition of Time Warner. (FT)
  • Campbell Soup (CPB) – The packaged food co. is still receiving bidding interest for its Arnott’s biscuits unit from three bidders including the Italian confectioner Ferrero. (Newswires)
  • CBS (CBS) – The broadcaster has announced a strategic partnership with Canvs, an AI company which will help CBS analyse emotional responses to survey questions. (Newswires)
  • Deere (DE) – The industrials co. has promoted John May to COO and President, after 22 years at the co. (Newswires)
  • General Dynamics (GD) – The defence co. has been awarded a USD 1.36bln army contract for maintenance services to support the Stryker family of vehicles, expected completion in 2024. (Newswires)
  • Hilton (HLT) – The hotels/resorts co. has raised its share repurchase authorisation by USD 1.5bln to USD 1.9bln. (Newswires)
  • Kroger (KR), Visa (V) – The supermarket conglomerate has stopped taking Visa payments at a second unit now, Smith's Food & Drug Stores, citing the high fees it charges retailers. (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – The aerospace/defence co. has been awarded a few large contracts, including a USD 830mln modification contract for missile defence systems, as well as a USD 680mln Army contract modification for radar tracking. (Newswires)
  • Newmont Mining (NEM) – Barrick Gold (GOLD) CEO has ruled out increasing his offer for Newmont Mining, where Barrick has valued Newmont at USD 10bln in an all-share transaction. (FT)
  • Southwest Airlines (LUV) – The co. is suing a mechanic’s union over instructing labourers to purposefully keep its planes grounded to gain leverage in contract talks. (CNBC)
  • TechnipFMC (FTI) – The oilfield engineering co. has been awarded a “large” contract by BP (BP LN) offshore on the maritime border of Mauritania and Senegal, estimated to be between USD 500mln-1bln. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Amazon (AMZN) – New York Governor Cuomo has been talking to Amazon executives over the past few weeks to bring back its HQ2 to NYC, NY Times reports. In addition, multiple CEOs from large companies have urged the co. to revise its plan to withdraw from NYC. (NY Times/Newswires)
  • Casino names (LVS, MGM, WYNN, MLCO) – The Macau, Asia region reported February casino revenue increased by 4.4% YY. (Newswires)
  • eBay (EBAY) – The online auction website has launched strategic changes with activist investors Elliott and Starboard, which includes an operational review, a review of its assets and two new board members. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co.’s enterprise platform Workplace, a Slack competitor, has 2mln paying users according to TechCrunch citing Facebook. WSJ reports Facebook is facing 10 investigations in Ireland over privacy law. (TechCrunch/WSJ)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – CEO Elon Musk said that he does not expect the automaker to be profitable in Q1 but returning to profitability in Q2 is “likely”, CNBC reports. Musk also said that the co. will be closing down stores and moving all sales globally to its online store in order to reduce the Model 3 price to USD 35,000, the co. is also reducing spending on sales and marketing. Elsewhere, Musk will switch his legal representation to Hueston Hennigan from Williams & Connolly as he battles with the SEC. (CNBC/Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Caesars (CZR) – The casinos/resorts co., alongside investor Carl Icahn, has appointed three new board members: Keith Cozza, Courtney Mather and James Nelson. (Newswires)
  • Las Vegas Sands (LVS) – The casinos/resorts co.’s CEO Sheldon Adelson has been diagnosed with cancer and reportedly has not been working since December, the co. says it expects him to return after his treatment has concluded. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 1st March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indicies are in the green [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%], following from the positive sentiment in Asia
  • Dollar somewhat stronger, as safe havens suffer on risk sentiment
  • China’s Caixin Manufacturing PMI beat expectations, but remains in contraction
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Core PCE, US ISM Manufacturing PMI, Canadian GDP, Fed’s Bostic

ASIA

Asian equities started the first trading day of the month on an optimistic note, despite a relatively downbeat session on Wall Street where the three main indices closed lower by around three-tenths of a percent. The Dow was weighed on by UnitedHealth shares which trimmed around 50 points off the index, meanwhile Nasdaq was pressured as heavyweights Facebook, Apple and Netflix all fell over 0.5%. In terms of February performance, Dow rose 3.7%, S&P gained 3.0% and Nasdaq advanced 3.4% in the month. ASX 200 (+0.4%) extended on opening gains as IT and healthcare names led the advances, whilst heavy-exporter Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) outperformed on the back of a weaker domestic currency. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp (+1.8%) was choppy as the third straight month of contraction in China’s manufacturing sector capped upside in the index, despite MSCI quadrupling China A-share weightings in global benchmarks to 20%. Goldman Sachs estimates that the MSCI move would lead to a potential USD 70bln net buying in A-shares, skewed towards the healthcare and consumer sectors. Finally, Hang Seng (+0.6%) edged higher during the session as the index felt support from its heavy-weight financial and energy sectors.

PBoC set the CNY mid-point at 6.6957 (Prev. 6.6901) (Newswires)

PBoC drains a net CNY 40bln on the day

China Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 49.9 vs. Exp. 48.5 (Prev. 48.3); third month of contraction (Newswires)
China New orders 50.2 (Prev. 47.3); highest in three-months

MSCI are to boost China A-shares weighting in global benchmarks to 20% from 5% in three steps. (WSJ)

NORTH AMERICA

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said signs of upward pressure on inflation is muted whilst reiterating that the US economy is in a good place and that the Fed remains patient. Powell also urges policies to boost labour force participation and productivity and noted that the recent rise in productivity leaves room for wages to rise without increasing inflation concerns. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Hasset said they are looking at 3% domestic growth rather than 2% due to the tax bill. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the Republicans who vote against the Mexican border wall are putting themselves in great jeopardy. (Fox News)

US President Trump said he will fight the Mueller report if it is not honest. (Fox News)

US President Trump reportedly commanded his former Chief of Staff, John Kelly, to grant Senior Presidential Advisor and son-in-law Jared Kushner a top-secret security clearance, ignoring concerns from intelligence officials; according to New York Times citing sources. (New York Times)

Canadian PM Trudeau is expected to announce a Cabinet reshuffle later today; according to local media. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said he believes a good deal with North Korea will happen and added that North Korea did not want to fully denuclearise. Meanwhile, North Korea Foreign Minister said if US lifts sanctions, North Korea will denuclearise, whilst adding that Pyongyang will not change its stance even if the US seeks further talks. US Secretary of State Pompeo said that North Korea basically asked for all sanctions to be lifted. (Newswires/BBC/Fox News)

US President Trump reportedly told North Korea to "go all in" on their commitment to denuclearise, but North Korea reportedly asked for all sanctions to be lifted apart from armaments; according to a senior state department official. (Newswires)

South Korean President Moon said the Trump-Kim Summit made meaningful progress. (Newswires)

Four Chinese navy ships have been spotted near the China-Taiwan-Japan disputed Senkaku islands; according to NHK. (NHK)

Pakistan's Foreign Minister states the downed Indian pilot will be released at the Wagah border on Friday. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Opposition Labour Party is reportedly moving towards a compromise plan which would allow PM May’s Brexit deal to pass but makes it clear that Parliament “withholds support” until the deal has been put to a public vote; according to multiple party sources. (The Guardian)

USTR Office said it will ensure "fair, balance and reciprocal trade" with the UK by reducing or eliminating tariffs. US seeks "comprehensive market access" for agricultural goods, and comprehensive duty-free market access to the UK for US industrial goods and address non-tariff barriers. (Newswires)

The Independent Group has named Chuka Umunna as its spokesman. (Sky News)

BoE’s Carney states that the UK business investment decline is huge, and that it is virtually essential to have a transition period. (Newswires)

Internal report by the German Parliament warns that a Brexit extension beyond the EU elections in May breaks EU laws, legal action against the UK is the only possible consequence; according to Welt's Bolzen. (Twitter)

In its annual report on the UK, the EU has accused Britain of enabling tax avoidance by large businesses, claiming the UK’s dividend tax arrangements may it attractive for “treaty shopping” and “aggressive tax planning”. (The Times)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Feb) 49.3 vs. Exp. 49.2 (Prev. 49.2)

- German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 47.6 vs. Exp. 47.6 (Prev. 47.6)

- French Markit Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.4)

EQUITIES

Major European equities are in the green [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.7%], as markets follow from the positive risk sentiment seen overnight in Asia. Dax (+1.0%) is the outperforming index with all components in the green on the positive risk sentiment following concerns over China’s economy being somewhat alleviated after Chinese Caixin manufacturing PMI came in stronger than expected; as such the Auto sector is outperforming its peers. Other notable movers include Rheinmetall (+7.3%) leading the Stoxx 600 after the Co’s FY18 revenue was in-line with expectations. WPP (+8.2%) are also firmly in the green in-spite of the Co’s outlook for 2019 being rather downbeat, particularly regarding the first half, as they reported results that marginally beat on expectations. Elsewhere, Man Group (-4.2%) are towards the bottom of the Stoxx 600 after stating that their funds under management fell in 2018.

FX

DXY- Although the Dollar has pared some of its post-GDP and Chicago PMI gains vs certain major counterparts, the index has rebounded further from sub-96.000 lows towards 96.400, largely at the expense of safe-haven currencies, and especially the Jpy.

JPY - No respite for the Yen after yesterday’s slide through 111.00 and accelerated losses below the 200 DMA as US Treasury yields continue to rally and the 10 year benchmark clears 2.70% in wake of the aforementioned stronger than forecast data and survey news. Usd/Jpy is now just a whisker away from the next big figure where more offers are touted, and with key Fib resistance residing not far above at 112.08.

CHF/GBP - Also victims of the broad Greenback revival, but the former unwinding more of its safe-haven premium as well, with the Franc back under parity vs the Buck and below 1.1350 against the Euro. Meanwhile, Cable’s pull-back from recent Brexit no deal highs has extended to 100+ pips and not far from Fib support around 1.3215, with little reaction or independent direction gleaned from a bang in line with consensus UK manufacturing PMI.

EUR - The single currency has pulled back further from best levels too (1.1400+), but holding up relatively well amidst mixed Eurozone data and perhaps with the aid of hefty option expiry interest at the 1.1350 level for today’s NY cut (2 bn) plus M&A news that has lifted Eur/Jpy very close to a key Fib. On that note, the 30 DMA in Eur/Usd at 1.1363 could also be influential on a closing basis along with 0.8593 in Eur/Gbp.

CAD/NZD/AUD - All on a firmer footing vs their US peer, and particularly the Loonie that has rebounded strongly from sub-1.3200 lows on Thursday ahead of Canadian GDP data and gleaning some traction from steadier oil prices. Usd/Cad is currently near the bottom of a 1.3132-77 range, and a big option expiry between 1.3140-50 may also have a bearing on trade given 1.4 bn rolling off later today. Meanwhile, the Kiwi and Aussie have both managed to regain composure and round number status after falling below 0.6800 and 0.7100, with some comfort drawn from the overnight Caixin Chinese manufacturing PMI that was sub-50 again, but not as weak as the official version.

FIXED INCOME

Several more twists and turns in bonds as debt markets kick off the new month rather indecisively, but with an offered tone for choice. Indeed, Gilts embarked on a deeper downturn from 125.87 Liffe highs in wake of the UK PMI and BoE data, albeit belatedly, to a marginal new intraday low of 125.67 before finding more underlying bids, while Bunds continue to meaner between 165.12-38 and the Eurozone semi-core/periphery underperform (slightly) in wake of France’s wider January budget shortfall and Spain joining Italy on the contractionary manufacturing PMI front. Elsewhere, it’s a bit deeper and steeper for the US Treasury curve as attention shifts to personal income, spending, the Fed’s preferred core PCE price measure, Markit/ISM manufacturing surveys and the final Michigan sentiment readings for February.

COMMODITIES 

Brent (U/C) and WTI (+0.1%) prices are essentially flat, in-spite of trading positively overnight and initially during the European session, although they are once again trading within a fairly narrow range of less than USD 2/barrel. Elsewhere, since the imposition of US sanctions on the 28th January on Venezuelan oil, Venezuela’s oil exports have dropped by 40% for the month to around 920k BPD. Separately, Lukoil have agreed to reach the OPEC+ targets in April, and Rosneft’s VP state that they fully comply with the pact.

Gold (-0.3%) is weaker as the USD moves higher recouping recent losses, with the yellow metal hitting a two-week low and currently trading around USD 1306/oz; however, analysts do highlight that the metal has strong support at the USD 1300/oz level. Elsewhere, copper weakened following China printing a 3rd month of contraction in their Caixin Manufacturing PMI, although the metal did recover as the figure was above expectations and risk sentiment remained positive. Separately, Goldman Sachs trade ideas include Long Dec’19 copper vs. Dec’19 zinc, Long jun’19 and short June’20 aluminium.

Returning to Liffe, the 10 year UK benchmark began Friday’s session flat at 125.79 and then slipped to 125.69, but has subsequently erased losses and rebounded to 125.87 before topping out, while the Short Sterling strip is now flat to a fraction firmer vs 0.5-1 tick below yesterday’s closing levels at one stage. content: Another fleeting bounce off the open and fade for the 10 year German debt future amidst a broad upturn in risk sentiment overnight, and with German retail sales rising well above expectations in contrast to the recent run of mostly disappointing data/survey news. Bunds just retreated to 165.12 vs a high of 165.38 and Thursday’s 165.31 close, which from a technical standpoint looks even more bearish as it eclipses yesterday’s session low and the 50% retracement level of this year’s rally. Back to fundamentals, Eurozone manufacturing PMIs will be in focus along with more German data in the form of February’s jobs report, then prelim inflation and January’s unemployment rate for the bloc as a whole.

**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

1st March 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equities started the first trading day of the month on an optimistic note, despite a relatively downbeat session on Wall Street where the three main indices closed lower by around three-tenths of a percent. The Dow was weighed on by UnitedHealth shares which trimmed around 50 points off the index, meanwhile Nasdaq was pressured as heavyweights Facebook, Apple and Netflix all fell over 0.5%. In terms of February performance, Dow rose 3.7%, S&P gained 3.0% and Nasdaq advanced 3.4% in the month. ASX 200 (+0.4%) extended on opening gains as IT and healthcare names led the advances, whilst heavy-exporter Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) outperformed on the back of a weaker domestic currency. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp (+0.1%) was choppy as the third straight month of contraction in China’s manufacturing sector capped upside in the index, despite MSCI quadrupling China A-share weightings in global benchmarks to 20%. Goldman Sachs estimates that the MSCI move would lead to a potential USD 70bln net buying in A-shares, skewed towards the healthcare and consumer sectors. Finally, Hang Seng (+0.3%) edged higher during the session as the index felt support from its heavy-weight financial and energy sectors.

FTSE

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 1st March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stock kicked the month off on the front foot, Nikkei 225 outperformed, Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI beat forecast but remained in contraction
  • UK Opposition Labour Party is reportedly moving towards a compromise plan which would allow PM May’s Brexit deal to pass in exchange for a 2nd referendum
  • In FX markets, DXY remained near post-GDP highs, AUD wobbled on China data, JPY weakened on risk appetite
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Unemployment Data, EZ Manufacturing PMI (Final) & CPI (Flash), UK Manufacturing PMI, US Core PCE & Retail Sales, US ISM Manufacturing PMI, Canadian GDP, Fed’s Bostic

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities started the first trading day of the month on an optimistic note, despite a relatively downbeat session on Wall Street where the three main indices closed lower by around three-tenths of a percent. The Dow was weighed on by UnitedHealth shares which trimmed around 50 points off the index, meanwhile Nasdaq was pressured as heavyweights Facebook, Apple and Netflix all fell over 0.5%. In terms of February performance, Dow rose 3.7%, S&P gained 3.0% and Nasdaq advanced 3.4% in the month. ASX 200 (+0.4%) extended on opening gains as IT and healthcare names led the advances, whilst heavy-exporter Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) outperformed on the back of a weaker domestic currency. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp (+0.1%) was choppy as the third straight month of contraction in China’s manufacturing sector capped upside in the index, despite MSCI quadrupling China A-share weightings in global benchmarks to 20%. Goldman Sachs estimates that the MSCI move would lead to a potential USD 70bln net buying in A-shares, skewed towards the healthcare and consumer sectors. Finally, Hang Seng (+0.3%) edged higher during the session as the index felt support from its heavy-weight financial and energy sectors.

PBoC set the CNY mid-point at 6.6957 (Prev. 6.6901) (Newswires)

PBoC drains a net CNY 40bln on the day

China Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Feb) 49.9 vs. Exp. 48.5 (Prev. 48.3); third month of contraction (Newswires)
China New orders 50.2 (Prev. 47.3); highest in three-months

MSCI are to boost China A-shares weighting in global benchmarks to 20% from 5% in three steps. (WSJ)

UK/EU

UK Opposition Labour Party is reportedly moving towards a compromise plan which would allow PM May’s Brexit deal to pass but makes it clear that Parliament “withholds support” until the deal has been put to a public vote; according to multiple party sources. (The Guardian)

USTR Office said it will ensure "fair, balance and reciprocal trade" with the UK by reducing or eliminating tariffs. US seeks "comprehensive market access" for agricultural goods, and comprehensive duty-free market access to the UK for US industrial goods and address non-tariff barriers. (Newswires)

European Commission said the best way to attend the Costa amendment is through the withdrawal agreement and added that it will not negotiate such mini-deals. Note: Costa amendment looks to secure the rights of EU citizens in a no deal Brexit. (Newswires)

In its annual report on the UK, the EU has accused Britain of enabling tax avoidance by large businesses, claiming the UK’s dividend tax arrangements may it attractive for “treaty shopping” and “aggressive tax planning”. (The Times)

The Independent Group has named Chuka Umunna as its spokesman. (Sky News)

FX

FX markets were quiet as DXY remained near post-GDP highs and was little moved by comments from Fed Chair Powell who reaffirmed the central bank’s patient stance and reiterated that the US economy is in a good place. As such EUR/USD was little changed after finding some support at 1.1365, albeit the pair remained below its 50 DMA at 1.1388 (ahead of EZ inflation data) and similarly, GBP/USD was uneventful above 1.3250. Elsewhere, the release of above-forecast China Caixin manufacturing PMIs gave the AUD/USD some impetus to rise to session highs, although gains were then pared back as China’s manufacturing sector failed to come out of contraction territory. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses edged higher and the former breached its 100 DMA (111.42) to the upside during the session as the overall risk appetite influenced an unwind in risk premium. In February. GBP was the best performing G10 currency against the greenback, +1.2%, whilst AUD was the worst performer, -2.5%.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures gained more ground during Asia-Pac trade wherein the former advanced further above USD 57.00/bbl while the latter traded higher just above USD 66.50/bbl, although there was little in the way of newsflow for the complex. Elsewhere, gold was steady around two-week lows as the USD recouped recent losses. Meanwhile, copper saw some downside following the third month of manufacturing contraction from its largest consumer, China, although the red metal bounced off lows amid the overall positive risk-sentiment. Finally, China’s top steelmaking city, Tangshan has issued a level 1 smog alert from March 1st to 6th, which requires steel mills to cut output by 40-70% or stop production altogether, depending on their emission scale. Steel prices, alongside Dalian iron ore futures rose for a third consecutive day amidst supply worries and strong demand expectations.

Nigerian Energy Minister Kachikwu said Nigeria complied with OPEC+ cuts deal in February. (Newswires)

Canada's Alberta has increased April oil production limit to 3.66mln BPD from 3.56mln BPD in January. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he believes a good deal with North Korea will happen and added that North Korea did not want to fully denuclearise. Meanwhile, North Korea Foreign Minister said if US lifts sanctions, North Korea will denuclearise, whilst adding that Pyongyang will not change its stance even if the US seeks further talks. US Secretary of State Pompeo said that North Korea basically asked for all sanctions to be lifted. (Newswires/BBC/Fox News)

US President Trump reportedly told North Korea to "go all in" on their commitment to denuclearise, but North Korea reportedly asked for all sanctions to be lifted apart from armaments; according to a senior state department official. (Newswires)

South Korean President Moon said the Trump-Kim Summit made meaningful progress. Furthermore, US President Trump told President Moon and Japan's PM Abe that the US will continue to communicate with North Korea. (Newswires)

Russia and China have vetoed US-drafted UN Security Council resolution calling for free and fair elections, and unhindered aid access in Venezuela. (Newswires)

Four Chinese navy ships have been spotted near the China-Taiwan-Japan disputed Senkaku islands; according to NHK. (NHK)

NORTH AMERICA

Yields were higher across the curve, led by the belly; decent GDP data helped selling action, as well as a beat from the Chicago PMI. * US T-Note futures (H9) settled 5+ ticks lower at 121-24.

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said signs of upward pressure on inflation is muted whilst reiterating that the US economy is in a good place and that the Fed remains patient. Powell also urges policies to boost labour force participation and productivity and noted that the recent rise in productivity leaves room for wages to rise without increasing inflation concerns. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Dove, Non-voter) said balance sheet decision is "in particular" a group effort, need the balance sheet as a tool in the event of a downturn. Furthermore, Kaplan stated that the Fed should not be taking any action with rates through June; will take some months to evaluate US growth deceleration. He believes that US growth in 2019 will be slower given a fall in fiscal stimulus and higher rates; looking at global growth, interest-rate sectors and credit spreads for effects on corporate profits and the job market and added said current interest rate is in the neutral range. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (Non-voter, Dovish) said one hike in 2019 and one in 2020 is appropriate. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Hasset said they are looking at 3% domestic growth rather than 2% due to the tax bill. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the Republicans who vote against the Mexican border wall are putting themselves in great jeopardy. (Fox News)

US President Trump said he will fight the Mueller report if it is not honest. (Fox News)

US President Trump reportedly commanded his former Chief of Staff, John Kelly, to grant Senior Presidential Advisor and son-in-law Jared Kushner a top-secret security clearance, ignoring concerns from intelligence officials; according to New York Times citing sources. (New York Times)

Canadian PM Trudeau is expected to announce a Cabinet reshuffle later today; according to local media. (Newswires)
